newsitem.title: JORDAN: Jordan divests key stake in cement firm.
newsitem.headline: Jordan divests key stake in cement firm.

text.p: Jordan, in the first major sale of a key holding in a profitable majority state-owned company, hopes to divest a 20 percent stake in Cement Factories Company to a strategic foreign partner by next November.

"This is the first experiment of its kind for Jordan on the global level to offer stock of some of the profitable companies to international firms," Mohammed Bataynah, general manager of Jordan Investment Corporation (JIC), the investment arm of the government, told Reuters on Tuesday.

Officials say the proposed sale is the first tangible step to sell a profitable majority state-owned concern under a privatisation plan key to success of Jordan's three-year IMF directed expanded economic reforms launched this year.

Officials say JIC, which owns parts of over 70 public shareholding companies listed in the Amman Financial Market with an estimated market value of around 500 million dinars ($706 million), is key to the success of the government's stepped up sell-off policy of listed companies.

JIC will reduce its share to 29.5 percent of Jordan Cement Factories Company's total 60 million dinar equity -- down from a 49.5 percent total stake. It is however restricting the sale to internationally established cement firms.
"We are not offering our stake to any foreign investor... we want the investor as a strategic investor who can provide the company with technical assistance and upgrade the industry, " Bataynah said.

Jordan Cement Factories Company, one of the highest capitalised firms listed in the Amman Financial Market, with a present 3.7 percent foreign ownership, has long attracted emerging market fund buying interest.

The firm, with a monopoly to produce cement under a 50 year concession that ends in 2001, has posted strong earnings over the last few years. It has posted a net profit of 10 million dinars at end of 1995 on 104 million dinar of sales.

Jordan Cement Factories, with an expansion programme to add up to 400,000 tonnes by 1997 from a present 3.5 million tonne annual capacity, plans to meet growth in regional markets and capture a key share of the one million tonne annual Palestinian market.
The World Bank has helped JIC in setting the selection guidelines for the sale of the stake to a strategic partner in the cement industry, Bataynah added.
JIC has already approached 16 international cement firms and provided them with well-defined bidding terms to streamline the selection process among potential investors.

French La Farge firm, Swiss-based Holder Bank, Belgian CBR Climenteries and Japanese Mitsubishi Materials are amongst international cement producers from as far as Korea and Mexico who have been recently approached directly by JIC.
Bidders will have to submit separate technical and financial offers by mid-October, under a scoring system that will qualify financial offers once their technical terms are acceptable.
After evaluating both offers the selection process among the foreign investors was expected to be completed by mid-November.
Bataynah said the government was expected to step up soon sell-offs in majority state-owned concerns or selling of large stakes in key public shareholding firms listed on the AMF.
"JIC expects the pace of privatisation to pick up by presenting potential investors with structured investment opportunities and a transparent bidding process," he said.
